blogposts.title: Week 1
blogposts.author: Kathy Weisensel
blogposts.content:
My first week at Nashville Software School was a complete whirlwind. Even though I had been anticipating the start of NSS's six-month bootcamp for months,
            I learned quickly that I wouldn't know what I was in for until I arrived. The biggest challenge so far? Retraining my brain.
            Working consistently for hours at a time to learn and apply new concepts is not something my brain has actively been engaged in for quite some time.
            As a lifelong lover of learning, I came into this program believing I had an edge; I have always thrived in a classroom environment and love the energy that comes from a group of people working through projects/ideas/problems together.
            Having been mostly self-employed for the past several years, and before that having worked in positions that did not require much active problem-solving, I realized this week that that part of my brain has been turned off, perhaps for years.
            Retraining my brain to absorb highly technical concepts, then apply those concepts in a concrete way, is a task that has been harder than I anticipated. Even as I'm writing this, I'm noticing that my writing skills have taken quite a hit this past week...
            is my right brain slowly deactivating to make room for a more activated left brain? Or am I just exhausted? (I imagine both.)
            One of my major accomplishments this week? I think I finally understand git and gitHub. Is that possible?

blogposts.title: Week 2
blogposts.author: Kathy Weisensel
blogposts.content:
Even though I undoubtedly remember creating a Week 2 blog post and updating it on GitHub, I have no evidence this actually happened.
            Instead of posting a Week 2 blog post, I've decided instead to try to summarize what has happened between April 8 and May 19.
            What stands out the most? Loads of self-doubt/loathing coupled with many nights spent in the fetal position asking myself 'why?' while my dogs looked on
            with some combination of worry and empathy. I may be exaggerating a little, but the overall theme of 'why-do-think-you-can-do-this, you-are-too-old/not-smart-enough' was a
            prevalent thought following me around. Here are some things I learned when I wasn't rocking back and forth, full fetal, in the corner:
            1) I am not an island, and software development cannot exist in a vacuum. There's a reason I wanted to enroll at NSS and not at some online school: I need to talk to people to be successful.
            Yes, I'm (sometimes painfully) introverted, but without commiseration with fellow students (and encouragement from instructors), I'd be completely
            at a loss. 2) For every terrible day, there was a good day. I'm not going to say great day, but good. I've learned to hold onto those good days in my mind and try to remember
            them when the bad days try to pull me down. It's progress.

blogposts.title: Week 8
blogposts.author: Kathy Weisensel
blogposts.content:
Week 8?!? Yes, I double checked. It's Week 8. I can't believe we are inching so closely towards the end of our front end course. In a month it will
            be over, and we'll be thinking about backend. I'm not going to lie, I'm really looking forward to diving into the backend. These past two weeks
            have taught me that I am more comfortable with, and more interested in dealing with data and a more systems-based approach. Learning how to use Firebase and how to work
            with APIs felt much more natural to me than other topics. I can understand how these concepts are applied and imagine a flow-chart in my head showing me how everything
            communicates with everything else. APIs were scary to me at first, but once I started imagining it as simply data sitting on a server somewhere, it's not so scary. It's just data.
            This week has definitely been my best so far, in terms of feeling confident in my own abilities, and feeling able to process all this new information without
            much anxiety. I know stuff!
